awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Liquid Helium Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) Sample Holder for Atomic Imaging of Next-Generation Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to enable atomic- and nano-scale imaging of materials and devices at temperatures as low as 10 K through the development of a stable liquid helium transmission electron microscope (TEM) specimen holder. Though TEM imaging modalities are amongst the most powerful metrology tools used in materials science, a long-standing lack of stable ultra-low temperature capabilities limits the range of their application to materials and technologies that operate at relatively high temperatures.  Stable ultra-low-temperature capabilities are urgently needed for state-of-the-art TEM machines to enable scientific discovery and development across a broad range of emerging, previously inaccessible fields. This project targets and expands the electron microscopy market (expected to exceed $10 billion by 2028) which is rapidly growing in tandem with metrology needs of semiconductor, quantum device, renewable energy, and life-sciences markets.

This project includes the development and testing of a novel cryogenic specimen holder with high stability as well as the quantification of high-resolution TEM imaging and stability metrics at liquid helium temperatures. To successfully gather atomic resolution or high-quality spectroscopic data, high thermal and vibrational stability, long hold times, and precise temperature control are necessary. Current low-temperature holders are not only incapable of reaching cold enough temperatures, but they suffer from significant instabilities and thermal losses, heavily affecting image resolution. They rely on small cryogenic dewars which lead to severe temperature fluctuations and vibrations as the unstable cryogen (liquid helium) rapidly evaporates. This project incorporates an innovative design with controlled liquid helium flow cooling, vibration decoupling, and precise temperature regulation over long hold times.  The technology will result in the development of a commercial instrument that turns any TEM into an ultra-low-temperature imaging platform capable of characterizing novel materials for next-generation technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is a revolutionary tool that provides atomic resolution imaging and characterization of advanced technological materials.  It plays a central role across various fields such as semiconductors, structural biology, and metallurgy.  By enabling the visualization of atomic structures, TEM provides an understanding of the connection between the atomic structure of matter and its functionality.  For many next-generation technologies,  stable TEM imaging under cryogenic conditions down to liquid helium temperature has become a necessity and a high priority.  This is especially true for emerging fields such as quantum sensing, quantum computing, ultra-sensitive detectors, and cryogenic CMOS technology.  The process of cooling within a TEM system involves the use of specialized specimen holders, which dock onto the microscope and establish a thermal connection between the sample and a cooling source.

Achieving cooling to liquid helium temperatures is, however, a formidable challenge in the field of electron microscopy.  Current methods use a small cryogenic dewar attached to the holder to cool specimens, leading to poor performance: as the limited columen of cryogen evaporates, it introduces substantial vibrations, poor resolution, temperature instability, and attendent sample drift, all of which compromise the resolution and process of TEM imaging.  Due to its higher volatility, the use of liquid helium in such designs exacerbates these problems.  

This NSF Phase I project addressed these cryogenic cooling challenges in TEM by developing an innovative specimen holder featuring a continuous flow design.  This design involves a 'cold heat exchanger' through which liquid cryogen continuously flows.  Liquid helium is drawn from a significantly larger, mechanically separated helium tank, thus enabling extended operation times without interruption for up to 48 hours.  The instrument further incorporates a vibration damping interface.  Furthermore, precise control of cryogen flow along with the use of heaters allows for precise temperature regulation, with temperature fluctuations of less than 2 millikelvins.  The specimen holder is highly modular and compatible with major electron microscope manufacturer platforms.

The primary objectives of Phase I were to (1) design and implement a preliminary physical prototype capable of reaching low base temperatures with liquid helium cooling, (2) achieve +/-2 mK temperature stability, (3) sustain these conditions for extended durations, and (4) develop quantification metrics for resolution, base temperature, and sample drift.  Phase I succeded in all of these objectives.  A functional prototype capable of cooling down the sample to 23 K while reaching temperatures of less than 10 K at the heat exchanger was developed.  Its temperature can be adjusted and maintained to within 2 mK.  Thanks to the low temperature fluctuations, sample drift was found to be less than 1 A/s (0.37 A/s), which enables performing advanced microscopy techniques such as scanning TEM (STEM) imaging.

The most significant achievement of Phase I was demonstrating the feasibility of obtaining ultra-low temperature atomic imaging of quantum materials for next generation computing.  The resolution achieved was as fine as 0.8 A at base temperature.  This remarkable result indicates not only the technical soundness of the design approach taken in Phase I but also its potential to transform electron microscopy as it intersects with next-generation technology demands.

The efforts of Phase I have laid a strong foundation for addressing the challenges associated with TEM imaging at ulta low cryogenic temperatures.  The NSF Phase I project has led to innovations and training in manufacturing of high-vacuum equipment, electronics design, and cryogenic engineering, capabilities that intersect with various next-generation technology demands.  Leading institutions, national laboratories, and industrial research labs have expressed strong interest in these technical advancements, with early adopters utilizing the prototype to collect hitherto unreachable data on superconductors, organic crystals, and quantum materials.  Based on Phase I results and Phase II plans, major manufacturers of electron microscopes have initiated partnerships to enable wider adoption and distribution of this technology on their platforms.  Informed by Phase I outcomes, Phase II R&D will demonstrate and manufacture a transferable liquid helium TEM imaging technology for widespread adoption across leading research univeristies and national laboratories.
